author: potuz
content:
<@543900561460822016> (or any client dev). I am studying the feasibility of overloading the consolidations contract for other uses. I'll describe the other uses below but they are kinda irrelevant for my question. As far as I can see from that contract, it verifies the signature and simply creates a consolidation request with the two 48 byte pubkeys obtained from the calldata and the execution address which was verified from the signature. Then the EL does not care at all on what the CL does with that consolidation request. Is this correct?

For context, the CL does the following validation today: it checks that if the two pubkeys are the same then it transforms a 0x01 validator into a 0x02 validator. I want to add a new check in that if the second pubkey is of the form 0x0N00...00  and the first pubkey is a 0x0(N-1) validator, it will convert it into a 0x0N validator. This allows to onboard immediately any existing validator as a builder if they control the withdrawal credentials.

author: potuz
content:
More generally, I want to know if we can think of these sort of overloading of these contracts without the need to create new types of requests. We can have any sort of API as long as it extends the current established one, and reinterpret the 96 bytes of the calldata however we want. 

I get the feeling that for the EL this would be much better than adding new request types, dropping a new contract on the EVM, etc. I feel we have this machinery already in place and it should be safe and trivial to use it on the CL for free now

author: lightclient
content: Seems doable from my perspective, only concern I can think of off the top of my head is increasing the load on the precompile may cause the fee to increase without need - however for what you're describing here the increase in load will be negligible so not a worry

author: lightclient
content: Personally I worry about shoehorning new concepts into old and prefer adding new request types, tx types, etc when they are neccesitated, but I think I am in the minority on this take
